title.sort: INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF ADAPTIVE CONTROL AND SIGNAL PROCESSING

titleGroup.title: International Journal of Adaptive Control and Signal Processing
Int. J. Adapt. Control Signal Process.

lineatedText.line: Liping Yan, School of Automation, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China.

titleGroup.title: State estimation for asynchronous multirate multisensor nonlinear dynamic systems with missing measurements
L. YAN ET AL.
STATE ESTIMATION FOR ASYNCHRONOUS MULTIRATE MULTISENSOR DYNAMIC SYSTEM

affiliation.orgDiv: School of Information and Communication Engineering
affiliation.orgName: Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications

abstract.title: SUMMARY
abstract.p: This paper is concerned with the state estimation for a kind of nonlinear multirate multisensor asynchronous sampling dynamic system. There are N sensors observing a single target independently at multiple sampling rates, and the dynamic system is formulated at the highest sampling rate. Observations are obtained asynchronously, and each sensor may lose data randomly at a certain probability. The fused state estimate is generated using multiscale system theory and the modified sigma point Kalman filter. It is shown that our main results improve and extend the existing sigma point Kalman filter for which the samples are obtained multirate nonuniformly. Measurements randomly missing with Bernoulli distribution could also be allowed in this paper. Finally, the feasibility and efficiency of the presented algorithm is illustrated by a numerical simulation example.Copyright © 2012 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

note.p: Liping Yan, Yuanqing Xia and Mengyin Fu are also with Key Laboratory of Intelligent Control and Decision of Complex Systems, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China.

section.title: INTRODUCTION
section.p: In recent years, networked control systems and sensor technology has witnessed extraordinary growth . The state estimation problem for time delay , asynchronous , or uncertain system with bounded noises are studied for effective networked control, whereas most of the literatures assumed that the systems are linear. In engineering, most of the real systems are nonlinear. The state estimate for nonlinear systems, that is, nonlinear filtering, is a difficult yet important task.

Theoretically, the optimal nonlinear filter may be generated by the use of Bayesian techniques, whose main idea is to estimate the probability density function of the nonlinear state on the basis of the given observations . However, because of the large dimensions of the real systems, to generate the optimal estimate is very complex and even impossible. To this end, many suboptimal nonlinear methods are presented, which may be classified into three groups. Namely, the analytical approximation (or function approximation) methods, the positive sampling methods, and the random sampling methods . The representatives for each class are the extended Kalman filter (EKF) , the sigma point Kalman filter (SPKF) , and the particle filter , respectively. EKF is known to be effective to the systems that are linear or near linear, which has poor robustness. Theoretically, particle filter can generate the optimal state estimate on condition that particles are properly chosen and used. However, it has very large computation complexity and the precision of the algorithm depends strongly on the sampling methods. SPKF is a kind of positive sampling method, which can achieve second order or higher accuracy, whose computational complexity is of the same order as the EKF and whose implementation is often substantially easier and requires no analytic derivation of Jacobians as was necessary in the EKF. Consequently, SPKF is popular and widely used in recent years . Considering networked control systems, H ∞ filtering for nonlinear stochastic systems with missing measurements is studied in and the state estimation of constrained nonlinear discrete‐time system is studied in . However, multisensor data fusion is not considered here.

Multisensor data fusion is a technique about how to best extract useful information from multiple sensors and obtain the optimal state estimates, which is widely used in various applications such as target tracking, surveillance, robot navigation, signal and image processing, and large‐scale systems . Aimed at linear systems, there are many multisensor data fusion algorithms, where the observations may be obtained synchronously or asynchronously, at the same sampling rate or at multiple rates, with or without data dropout . For the data fusion of nonlinear dynamic systems, the algorithms are a few . When data dropout and asynchronous data sampling with multiple sampling rates are concerned, which are common in networked control system, the data fusion state estimation algorithms for nonlinear systems are rare .

In , SPKF is used to fuse multisensor information when the data from multiple sensors are obtained synchronously and at the same sampling rate. In this paper, we will extend SPKF to the data fusion problem when there are multiple sensors observing a single target at multiple rates, and the sampling are asynchronous and nonuniform, and the data are dropped out randomly at a given probability. We will present the state estimation algorithm and give theoretical analysis besides simulations.

This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 is the problem formulation. In Section 3, the asynchronous multirate multisensor data fusion algorithm for a class of nonlinear system is presented by use of multiscale system theory and by modifying SPKF. Section 4 is the numerical simulation, and Section 5 reaches the conclusion.

section.title: PROBLEM FORMULATION
section.p: A class of nonlinear dynamic system with multiple sensors observing a single target at different sampling rates and sample asynchronously with measurements randomly missing could be described by the following : x(kN + 1) = f(x(kN)) + w(kN) yi(ki) = γi(ki)ℏi(x(ki)) + vi(ki),i = 1,2,…,N, where is the system equation. x(kN) ∈ Rn is the state vector at time kNT, where T is the sampling period of Sensor N. f(*) is the system model, which is determined by nonlinear function f. w(kN) ∈ Rn×1 is supposed to be a zero‐mean white Gaussian noise whose variance is Q(k). Equation is the measurement equation. i = 1,2, … ,N denotes sensors, whose sampling rates are Si, respectively. is the kith measurement observed by Sensor i, and ℏi(*) is the measurement model that can be determined by nonlinear function ℏi. The sampling of different sensors are asynchronous, and the sampling rates meet Si = SN∕ni,1 ≤ i ≤ N −1, where ni are known positive integers. The measurement noise is supposed to be a zero‐mean white Gaussian noise with variance being Ri(ki),i = 1,2, … ,N.

The initial value of the state vector x(0) is a random vector, whose mean and estimation error covariance are x0 and P0, respectively. It is assumed that x(0), w(kN), and vi(ki) are mutually independent.

The variable γi(ki) ∈ R is a stochastic sequence that takes values on 0 and 1 with Bernoulli distribution, whose expectation is γ̄i, which is used to describe the degree of measurements missing. It is assumed that γi(ki) is independent of w(kN), vi(ki), and x(0),i = 1,2, … ,N.

The objective of this paper is to develop an algorithm, which can effectively fuse the measurements observed by different sensors with asynchronous sampling at multiple rates in case of stochastic data dropout, to generate the optimal estimate of state x(k).
Remark
For simplicity and without lose of generosity, we denote kN = k and set T = 1 in the sequel.
Remark
In this paper, nonlinear system filter is studied on condition that multiple sensors observe a single target at different sampling rates asynchronously. The asynchronous multirate multisensor dynamic system is described at different scales. This system involves four indices: a sensor index, a scale index, a data block index, and a time index. The scale index and the sensor index are both denoted by i (as in ). The bigger i, the finer the scale is. For instance, i = N denotes the finest scale, in which the sensor samples fastest. i = N −1,N −2, … ,2 denote coarser scales, whereas i = 1 denotes the coarsest scale, where the sensor samples slowest. It is assumed that Sensor N (at the highest sampling rate) should sample uniformly, whereas any other Sensor i(1 ≤ i ≤ N −1) sample nonuniformly. The measurements of Sensor N can be divided into blocks, and the length of each block m(n1,n2, … ,nN−1) is the least common multiple of n1,n2, … , and nN−1. yN(k) is the kth measurement observed by Sensor N at time k. For i = 1,2, … ,N −1, yi(ki) is the kith measurement observed by Sensor i, which is obtained at the time instant between ni(k −1) + 1 and nik. The sampling of different sensors are asynchronous. For example, in Figure , Sensor 3 samples fastest, the sampling rates of Sensors 2 and 1 are 1∕2 and 1∕3 of Sensor 3, respectively. That is, n2 = 2, n1 = 3, and the length of each data block is 6. Sensor 3 at the highest sampling rate samples uniformly, whereas Sensors 2 and 1 sample nonuniformly. Namely, y3(k) is obtained at time k, y2(k2) is obtained at the time between 2k −1 and 2k, and y1(k1) is obtained between 3k −2 and 3k. We refer the readers to , , for more details.
Remark
The system to be studied is nonlinear, where the dynamic system model is formulated in the finest scale, whereas the measurement equations are formulated at different scales. The sensors that observe the target with higher sampling rates are at finer scales. For i = 1,2, … ,N −1, x(ki) is the coarse projection of the state x(k) from scale N to scale i. When there is no prior information available, the state x(ki) at scale i may be approximated by the states at scale N through the following formula :
where ni is the sampling rate ratio of sensor N to sensor i, i = 1,2, … ,N.

section.title: ASYNCHRONOUS MULTIRATE MULTISENSOR DATA FUSION ALGORITHM
section.p:
In this section, the SPKF‐based asynchronous multirate multisensor data fusion algorithm is presented on the basis of the problem formulation in Section 2. Before that, the measurement equation should be rewritten properly.
Theorem
Assume f is invertible, then the measurement equation can be rewritten as follows: yi(ki) = γi(ki)hi(x(nik)) + vi(ki),i = 1,2,…,N, where
and where f0 = I denotes the identical transformation, f−1 denotes the invert transformation of f, and nN = 1.
Proof
The proof can be found in Appendix A.□

In the sequel, on the basis of models and and the SPKF, we will first generate the asynchronous multirate multisensor data fusion algorithm under the assumption that data missing did not happen. When data dropout is concerned, we will introduce the data fusion algorithm afterwards.
Theorem
Assume f is invertible, the system model is formulated as in Section 2. At time k, it is assumed that there are p ′ + 1 sensors that meet mod (k,nip) = 0, where p = 0,1,2, … ,p ′ and N = i0 > N −1 ≥ i1 ≥ i2 ≥ … ≥ ip′ ≥ 1. The optimal state estimate x̂(k −1|k −1) and the corresponding estimation error covariance P(k −1 | k −1) at time k −1 have been generated. Then, the optimal state estimate x̂(k|k) and the estimation error covariance P(k | k) can be deduced on the basis of SPKF by using formulas –: x̂(k|k) = x̂ip′(k|k) P(k|k) = Pip′(k|k), where for p = 1,2, … ,p ′ , we have
For p = 0, the initial state estimate and the estimation error covariance are computed by x̂i0(k|k) = x̂(k|k −1) + KN(k)[yN(k) −ŷN(k|k −1)] Pi0(k|k) = P(k|k −1) −KN(k)PỹN(k|k −1)KNT(k), where
X(l; k|k −1) = f(X(l; k −1)); l = 0,1,…,2n
YN(l; k|k −1) = ℏN(X(l; k|k −1)) The related parameters are
Generally speaking, one has κ = 0, 10−3 < α ≤ 1, β = 2.
Proof
The proof can be found in Appendix B.□
Corollary
For sensor i, if yi(ki) is missing or faulty, the data fusion algorithm is similar to Theorem , except that the innovation matrix Ki(k∕ni) in Equation (if i = ip) or (if i = N) is set to be zero. From Theorem , when yip(kip) is missing or faulty, we have
which can be obtained by setting Kip(k∕nip) = 0. Whether yi(ki) is true or false (missing) may be verdicted by the following equation:
where μ is a scalar that is not less than 4. □
Remark
Because w(kN) and vi(ki) are assumed to be Gaussian noises, from Theorem , we have that (yi(ki) −ŷi(ki)) is Gaussian distributed for each ki and E{[yi(ki) −ŷi(ki)][yi(ki) −ŷi(ki)]}≈ Ri(ki). From the property of the normal distribution, one has , where P(A) means the probability of A. So, if we choose μ no less than 4, is true in the probability of no less than 0.9544, and if we choose μ no less than 9, is true in the probability of no less than 0.997.

The realization of the algorithm can be summarized as follows:
Rewrite the measurement equation by using Theorem .
Use Theorem or Corollary to generate the optimal state estimate, that is,
Compute the state prediction x̂(k|k −1) and the corresponding estimation error covariance P(k | k −1) by using system model and formulas –.
For i = N, compute the initial state estimate x̂i0(k|k) and the corresponding estimation error covariance Pi0(k|k) by using the rewritten measurement equation and formulas , , and –.
For p ≥ 1 and ip ∈ [1,N −1], judge whether k can be divided completely by nip. If true, then compute x̂ip(k|k) and Pip(k|k) by using formulas – and by renovating . Otherwise, set p = p+ 1, return (iii).
Judge whether all the ip ∈ [1,N −1] that meet mod (k,nip) = 0 have been examined, and yip(k) have been used. If true, let p = p ′ , output x̂(k|k) = x̂ip′(k|k) and P(k|k) = Pip′(k|k). Otherwise, let p = p+ 1, return (iii).

The flow chart of the algorithm is shown in Figure , where the horizontal axis denotes time and the vertical axis denotes sensors. When the optimal state estimate and the estimation error covariance have been generated at time k −1, to generate the optimal state estimate at time k, the information observed by sensor N is first used along the time axis (horizontal axis). After that, at time k, information obtained by other sensors are fused along the vertical axis (the sensor axis). Finally, when all the information until time k has been fused, the optimal state estimate x̂(k|k) at the finest scale is generated.

figure.caption: The illustration of SPKF‐based asynchronous multirate multisensor data fusion algorithm.

section.p:
From Theorem and Corollary , it is obvious that we have the following theorem.
Theorem
The state estimation algorithm presented by Theorem and Corollary is meaningful, and we have
where PS(k | k) is the estimation error covariance at time k by SPKF based on model and single sensor measurement, that is, when set N = 1 in .
Proof
From , Theorem can be deduced directly.□
Remark
In fact, the strict inequality in Theorem holds except at most the first n̄ points, where n̄ =min{ni,i = 1,2,…,N}. This can be seen directly from formula because Pỹip(k nip) is generally positive. Therefore, from the convergence of SPKF and Theorem , one can conclude that the presented data fusion algorithm is convergent and effective and the SPKF is generalized successfully to data fusion of nonlinear systems when the different sensors are observing a single target at multiple rates and are sampled asynchronously, even with data randomly missing.

section.title: NUMERICAL SIMULATION
section.p: In this section, we will illustrate the effectiveness of the presented algorithm by an example.

Consider the following nonlinear dynamic system : x(k + 1) = A(k)x(k) + w(k) yi(ki) = ℏi(x(ki)) + v(ki),i = 1,2, where
x(ki,1) and x(ki,2) denote the first and second dimensions of x(ki), respectively. The system model matrix meet A(k) = 0.906I2 × 2. The system noise and the measurement noises are assumed to be Gaussian distribution with zero mean. The sampling rate of Sensor 1 is half of Sensor 2. The variances are Q = 0.01I2 × 2, R1 = 0.01, and R2 = 0.01, respectively. The initial state and the corresponding error variance are x0 = [10 10]T and P0 = I2 × 2, respectively.

The Monte Carlo simulations of 30 runs are shown in Table and Figures , where Figures are the simulation of data fusion without data dropout and Figures are the simulation results of data fusion with data missing at the probability of 0.2 for each sensor.

tabular.title: The statistical means of the absolute values of the estimation errors.

figure.caption: The measurements of sensors 2 and 1 without data missing.
The estimate of the first dimension.
The estimation error of the first dimension.
The measurements of sensors 2 and 1 with data missing.
The estimate of the first dimension based on missing measurements.
The estimation error of the first dimension based on missing measurements.

section.p: The values listed in Table are the means of the absolute values of the estimation errors, which are computed by , where K = 300 denotes the number of the sampling points of Sensor 2, J = 30 denotes the Monte Carlo simulation runs, whereas x̃j(k|k) denotes the estimation error of the state at the jth run. In Table , four schemes are tested and listed: (i) the EKF of Sensor 2; (ii) the SPKF result of Sensor 2; (iii) the fused result of sensors 1 and 2 with the use of EKF; and (iv) the fused result of sensors 1 and 2 with the use of the presented algorithm. The second and the third rows of Table denote the statistical means of the absolute values of the estimation errors of the first and the second dimensions, respectively, with the assumption that data dropout do not happen. The fifth and the sixth rows denote those fusing partial data with partial measurements randomly missing.

For either the second or the third rows, comparing the second with the third columns of Table , one can notice that SPKF is more effective than EKF. Comparing the third with the fifth columns of Table , one can see that the presented data fusion algorithm is effective.

Figures and show the measurements of sensors 2 and 1 in case of without data dropout and with data dropout, respectively, where (a) denotes the measurements of sensor 2 of dimension 1, (b) denotes the measurements of sensor 1 of dimension 1, (c) denotes the measurements of sensor 2 of dimension 2, and (d) denotes the measurements of sensor 1 of dimension 2.

Figures and show the state estimate of Monte Carlo simulation result at one run, where the real blue line denote the original signal and the dashed red line denote the estimates of different cases: (a) denotes the estimated signal by using EKF based on Sensor 2, (b) denotes the signal estimated by using SPKF for Sensor 2, and (c) and (d) denote the fused results by using EKF and the presented algorithm, respectively. For each figure, comparing (b) with (a), or (d) with (c), one can find that the SPKF‐based algorithm is more effective than the EKF‐based algorithm.

Figures and are the statistical state estimation errors of the first dimension without and with data randomly missing at probability of 0.2, respectively, where (a), (b), (c), and (d) denote the statistical error of EKF, SPKF, fused by EKF, and fused by SPKF, respectively. One can observe that (b) and (d) are more close to zero compared with (a) and (c), and (d) has the smallest absolute values. From these figures, one can see that whether without or with data randomly missing, the asynchronous multirate multisensor data fusion algorithm by using SPKF is convergent and effective.
Briefly, the simulation results in this section illustrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the presented algorithm.

section.title: CONCLUSIONS
section.p: In this paper, the SPKF is modified and generalized to the case that there are multiple sensors observing a single target at multiple rates that sample asynchronously when the dynamic model is nonlinear and the observations are lost at a certain probability. Theoretical analysis and simulation results show the feasibility and effectiveness of the presented algorithm.
The algorithm is applicable to many application fields, such as target tracking, integrated navigation, network control, fault diagnosis, and tolerance.

Therefore, the following equation can be deduced directly from and : yi(ki) = γi(ki)ℏi(x(ki)) + vi(ki) = γi(ki)ℏi(fi(x(nik))) + vi(ki) = γi(ki)(ℏi ⋅fi)(x(nik)) + vi(ki) (41) = γi(ki)hi(x(nik)) + vi(ki), where for i = 1,2, … ,N, it is denoted that

By definition, the optimal state estimate x̂(k −1|k −1) is obtained by using all the information observed by sensors i = 1,2, … ,N sampled before time k −1, that is, x̂(k −1|k −1) = E{x(k −1)|Y1li(i); i = 1,2,…,N,li = (k −1) ni}.

For x̂(k|k) to be generated, the information yip(k nip) should be used in sequence of p = 0,1,2, … ,p ′ . For p = 0, yN(k) is used to modify x̂(k −1|k −1), and x̂i0(k|k) could be obtained:

section.title: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
section.p: The work of Liping Yan was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation under grants 61004139 and 61004059 and the Science and Technology Support Program Research Base, Ministry of Education of China. The work of Bo Xiao was supported by the Beijing Science Foundation under grant 4123102 and the outstanding youth program of Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications. The work of Yuanqing Xia and Mengyin Fu were supported by the National Natural Science Foundation under grants 60974011 and 60904086, respectively.
